name: undefended
content:
undefended adjective
(NOT PROTECTED)
Add to word list
Add to word list
not protected against attack: It is the world's longest undefended international border. A hungry mink might find an undefended chickenhouse or fish pond.
in sports or games, having no one or nothing preventing the opposing player or players from scoring points, goals, etc. : She tapped the ball into an undefended net. He immediately took my undefended pawn with his queen.
More examplesFewer examplesThey realised their coastal frontiers were almost undefended, and they had to have a navy.The undefended Spanish town of Guernica was bombed in April 1937.Many residents said they had been evacuated while their homes were left undefended against the fires.An undefended shooter came in close to the net and tried to score.

undefended adjective
(NOT REPRESENTED)
(of someone accused of something in a court of law) having no lawyer acting for them: The court advised him to take up the case, as the prisoner was undefended. She will go on trial undefended because the government has put her lawyer under house arrest.

undefended adjective
(NOT CONTESTED)
mainly UK An undefended title in a competition is something that you won before and that no one else has been able to win again: She is also favourite for the undefended girls' 16-18 years 100m butterfly title. The women's 100m backstroke title is also undefended.
More examplesFewer examplesHe continues to use his undefended title as the highest of credentials.She will be among those contesting the undefended women's title.
